The Ministry of Defence Police (Conduct, Performance and Appeals Tribunals) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These changes bring Ministry of Defence Police discipline rules in line with recent reforms for regular police forces. Officers found guilty of gross misconduct – including automatic classification for serious criminal convictions – will now face mandatory dismissal unless extremely rare exceptions apply, removing previous discretion. The process speeds up too: disciplinary notices can be sent by email instead of post (with clear rules on when they count as received), and performance reviews are simplified from a three-step to a two-step system, requiring officers to prove improvement within three months. Former officers will typically face faster-track misconduct hearings unless they opt out. Overall, this tightens accountability, accelerates removal of unfit officers, and modernises procedures for staff and oversight bodies.

The Corporation Tax Act 2010 (Part 8C) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This law changes how businesses are taxed when HMRC pays them interest after wrongly collecting too much tax. Previously, businesses faced a punitive 45% tax on even small interest refunds. Now, they keep the full amount if the interest rate matches or falls below the government’s standard rate (currently 3.5%), meaning businesses receive larger refunds for HMRC errors. It also gives HMRC up to two years after a business’s financial year ends to collect the tax on higher-interest refunds, preventing missed deadlines during lengthy court disputes or settlements.

The Biocidal Products (Data Protection Periods) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These new rules extend by five years—until 31 December 2030—the period during which companies developing new biocidal products (like disinfectants, pesticides, or preservatives) keep exclusive rights to their safety data. This means competitors cannot legally use that data to copy and sell similar products before 2030, protecting the original developer's investment while regulators complete safety reviews for certain substances. It gives businesses clearer security to innovate and maintain market exclusivity for key products affecting public health and environmental safety.

title: The Borough Council of Calderdale (Elland Station and West Vale Access Package) (West Yorkshire Plus Transport Fund, Transforming Cities Fund) (Calder and Hebble Navigation Bridge) Scheme 2022 Confirmation Instrument 2025
The Broadcasting (Regional Programme-making and Original Productions) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: New rules let TV channels (ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5, and S4C) count repeat broadcasts of regional programmes toward their legal requirement to show locally made content. OFCOM must now decide exactly when repeats qualify. This change gives broadcasters flexibility to meet regional content targets using existing shows, potentially reducing pressure to commission entirely new local productions while keeping regional stories on screen. For S4C, the law also updates references to clearly name it as the Welsh-language broadcaster responsible for meeting these rules.

title: The Environmental Protection (Wet Wipes Containing Plastic) (England) Regulations 2025
summary: England now bans shops from selling plastic-containing wet wipes to the public to stop them clogging drains and polluting rivers. You can't buy these wipes in stores, but pharmacies can still supply them for medical needs, and businesses or councils can order them for professional use. Fines and forced shutdowns will hit shops breaking the rule, with enforcers inspecting premises and publishing violations. This means fewer plastic wipes ending up in sewers and waterways, protecting local environments and reducing clean-up costs for communities.

The Domestic Abuse Act 2021 (Commencement No. 6, 8 and 9 and Saving Provisions) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: Extends domestic abuse protection orders in England and Wales pilot areas until 31 March 2026, giving victims four extra months of immediate safety from abusers. Ensures courts can still issue or appeal these orders if applications were made before the original November 2025 pilot end date, even if decisions are pending. Police and courts keep using these tools to urgently separate victims from perpetrators without gaps in legal coverage.
